item.title: Error interface and error handling
item.description:
Error handling in the Go language is not quite the same as in other languages. It treats errors as a value. There is more emphasis on determining errors and handling them, rather than catching them directly with a catch

Error interface

The Go language treats errors as a special value and does not support the use of try/catch to catch exceptions.

The Go language uses an interface called error to represent error types.

1
2
3

type error interface {
    Error() string
}

The error interface contains only one method - Error() - and this function needs to return a string describing the error message.

When a function or method needs to return an error, we usually use the error as the last return value. For example, the following function in the standard library os opens a file.

1
2
3

func Open(name string) (*File, error) {
	return OpenFile(name, O_RDONLY, 0)
}

Since error is an interface type with a default zero value of nil, we usually compare the error returned by a function call with nil to determine whether the function returned an error. For example, you will often see error code like the one below.

1
2
3
4
5

file, err := os.Open("./xx.go")
if err != nil {
	fmt.Println("open file failure, err:", err)
	return
}

Notion

When we use the fmt package to print an error, the Error method of type error is automatically called, which means that a description of the error is printed.

Create Error

The easiest way to customize error is to use the New function provided by the errors package to create an error.

1

func New(text string) error

It takes a string argument to return an error containing that string. We can quickly create an error when the function returns.

1
2
3
4
5
6
7

func queryById(id int64) (*Info, error) {
	if id <= 0 {
		return nil, errors.New("Invalid id")
	}

	// ...
}

Or it can be used to define an error variable, for example the standard library io.EOF error is defined as follows.

1

var EOF = errors.New("EOF")

fmt.Errorf

When we need to pass in formatted error description information, using fmt.Errorf is a better choice.

1

fmt.Errorf("query failure, err:%v", err)

However, the above approach loses the original error type and only gets the textual information of the error description.

In order not to lose the error chain of function calls, using fmt.Errorf with the special formatting verb %w allows to repackage a new error based on an existing error.

1

fmt.Errorf("query failure, err:%w", err)

For such secondary wrapped errors, the following three methods are provided in the errors package.

1
2
3

func Unwrap(err error) error // get err contains the next level of error
func Is(err, target error) bool // Determine if err contains target
func As(err error, target interface{}) bool // Determine if err is of type target

Error structure type

In addition, we can define our own structure types to implement the error interface.

1
2
3
4
5
6
7
8
9

// OpError custom structure type
type OpError struct {
	Op string
}

// Error OpError type implements the error interface
func (e *OpError) Error() string {
	return fmt.Sprintf("No authority to perform %s operation", e.Op)
}

item.title: How to use go-humanize
item.description:
Late at night, I will open the computer and study some open source projects, not recently in the research found an open source project to use a very good Go language library: go-humanize.

This is a “humanize” Go language library, the meaning of humanize is not to describe the Go language library, but the Go language library to achieve the function, it can convert the number, time, capacity, etc. into our human easy to understand words, such as the capacity of the hard disk is 82854982 bytes, we can not understand very well, but if the capacity is 83M, then it is good to understand, go-humanize does this thing. humanize does just that.

Installation and use

This part is simple, we all know it well, first get this Go language library by go get command

1

➜ go get github.com/dustin/go-humanize

Then use import to import "github.com/dustin/go-humanize" and you’re ready to go.

Capacity Size Conversion

For example, the example of the hard disk can be easily transformed using the humanize.Bytes function.

1
2

// That file is 83 MB.
fmt.Printf("That file is %s.", humanize.Bytes(82854982))

It can convert such a long list of byte numbers to the easily understood 83MB, but it can do more than just convert to MB, it can be KB, GB, etc., and will choose the most appropriate unit based on the size of the byte.

1
2

// That file is 83 GB.
fmt.Printf("That file is %s.", humanize.Bytes(82854982000))

Add 3 zeros, that’s GB.

Time Conversion

Time conversion is the same, if a time is replaced by 3 minutes ago, 3 days ago will be easier to understand than the dry absolute time, use the humanize.Time function to get it done

1
2

// This was touched 7 hours ago.
fmt.Printf("This was touched %s.", humanize.Time(someTimeInstance))

This function is the same as humanize.Bytes, which also converts to xxx minutes ago xxx hours ago or xxx days ago, etc., depending on the relative time.

Kilobits

When we work with amounts, it is easier to read if we use thousandths, i.e. comma separation, and humanize provides this feature as well.

1
2

// You owe ￥6,582,491.
fmt.Printf("You owe ￥%s.\n", humanize.Comma(6582491))

It is handled as shown below.

1
2
3
4
5

0 -> 0
100 -> 100
1000 -> 1,000
1000000000 -> 1,000,000,000
-100000 -> -100,000

Summary

This library also provides other features, such as formatting floating-point numbers, you can remove the extra zeroes, for example, you can display the order by because, said the first xxx, you can learn to use these yourself, here no longer introduced.

An open source project can rely on multiple open source projects, so that the open source project will be built faster and more stable, standing on the shoulders of others, this is the contribution of open source.

item.title: A few must-have Golang tricks
item.description:
Go is a very good programming language. It is a language that allows you to really focus on your business and not have to worry too much about the program itself, so you can write applications as quickly as possible. For example, it has a relatively complete ecosystem that can provide you with everything you need to get started.

But then, it’s not a panacea, and there are some things we need to be aware of. I’m writing this article mainly as a reminder to myself, and also as some observations and summaries. Of course, these are just tips, not real problems, but of course if you notice them and use them in the real world, then it will benefit you a lot, which is the difference between a newbie and a veteran.

Do not use Logrus

This is actually related to generics. Because Go is a strongly typed static language, you can’t bypass data types like you can with NodeJS or PHP. So what if we still need to use generic types? Like Loger, for example, or ORM, because the only way to write generic code is to use generic types, otherwise you’d have to write each one once.

In the end, we have to use reflection. And Logrus makes heavy use of reflection, which leads to a lot of allocation counts. While not usually a big problem (depending on the code), performance is important, especially in large scale, highly concurrent projects. While this may sound like a very minor optimization, it is important to avoid reflections. If you see code that can use structure regardless of type, it will use reflection and have a performance impact.

For example, Logrus doesn’t care about types, but obviously Go needs to know (eventually).What does Logrus do? Use reflection to detect types, which is overhead.

1
2
3

  log.WithFields(log.Fields{
    "animal": myWhatever,
  }).Info("A walrus appears")

So I would prefer zerolog, but of course zap is good too. Both claim zero allocation, which is what we want, since they have the least performance impact.

Do not use encoding/json

When we need a function, function, many people suggest using the standard library. The exception is the encoding/json module in the standard library. In fact, like the example above, encoding/json uses reflection, which can lead to poor performance and losses when writing APIs that return json responses, or microservices.

You can use Easyjson, for example, which is simple and efficient, and uses a code generator to create the code needed to convert the structure to json to minimize distribution. This is a manual build step and is annoying. Interestingly json-iterator also uses reflection, but is significantly faster and I suspect black magic.

Do not use closures in goroutines if possible

For example, the following sample code

1
2
3
4
5

for i:=0;i<10;i++ {
  go func() {
     fmt.Println(i)
  }()
}

Most people probably expect this to print the numbers 0 through 9, just like when delegating the task to goroutine.

But the actual result: depending on the system, you will get one or two numbers and many 10s.

Why is this? Closures have access to the parent scope, so you can use variables directly. Although updated linters may warn you about “variable closure capture”, they do not require you to redeclare the variable.

Go’s reputation for performance owes much to the execution of runtime optimizations, which try to “guess” what you want to do and optimize certain execution paths. During this time, it “captures” variables and passes them to where they are needed in the most theoretically efficient way possible (for example, after completing some non-concurrent operation to free up some CPU allocations). The result in this case is that the loop may start goroutines, and the goroutines may receive the value of i from the parent scope much later. There is no guarantee which one you will see on multiple executions of this code, it could be the number 10 or some other number.

If you do use a closure for some reason, be sure to pass the variable i and treat the closure as you would every function.

Summary

There are definitely more than these three techniques in programming practice. Figuring them out and mastering them in practice will improve our programming skills and allow us to write more optimized code.

item.title: Command Line Usage of GoLang-flag package
item.description:
The Golang handles command line arguments by using the flag package from the standard library.

Package flag implements command-line flag parsing

http://golang.org/pkg/flag/

http://golang.org/pkg/

A few notes

define the flags to be used in the command line by flag.String(), Bool(), Int(), etc.

  • after defining the flag, call flag.Parse() to parse the command line parameters.

package main
 
import (
    "flag"
    "fmt"
)
 
var Input_pstrName = flag.String("name", "gerry", "input ur name")
var Input_piAge = flag.Int("age", 20, "input ur age")
var Input_flagvar int
 
func Init() {
    flag.IntVar(&Input_flagvar, "flagname", 1234, "help message for flagname")
}
 
func main() {
    Init()
    flag.Parse()
 
    // After parsing, the arguments after the flag are available as the slice flag.Args() or individually as flag.Arg(i). The arguments are indexed from 0 through flag.NArg()-1
    // Args returns the non-flag command-line arguments
    // NArg is the number of arguments remaining after flags have been processed
    fmt.Printf("args=%s, num=%d\n", flag.Args(), flag.NArg())
    for i := 0; i != flag.NArg(); i++ {
        fmt.Printf("arg[%d]=%s\n", i, flag.Arg(i))
    }
 
    fmt.Println("name=", *Input_pstrName)
    fmt.Println("age=", *Input_piAge)
    fmt.Println("flagname=", Input_flagvar)
}

output:
